docs.title: next-cvat
docs.text: A Python library for interacting with CVAT (Computer Vision Annotation Tool).

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install next-cvat

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
from next_cvat import Client

# Initialize client from environment variables
client = Client.from_env_file(".env.cvat.secrets")

# Get a project
project = client.project(217969)

# Download project data
project.download_("dataset/")

# Load annotations
from next_cvat import Annotations
annotations = Annotations.from_path("dataset/annotations.xml")

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Easy-to-use Python interface for CVAT
  • Support for projects, tasks, jobs, and annotations
  • Download and upload functionality
  • Mask annotation support
  • Job status tracking
  • Comprehensive type hints and documentation

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The library provides several key components:

docs.title: Client
docs.text:
The main entry point for interacting with CVAT. Handles authentication and provides access to projects, tasks, and jobs.

View Client Documentation →

docs.title: Annotations
docs.text:
Load, save, and query CVAT annotations. Track job status and manage annotation data.

View Annotations Documentation →

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
Rich set of data types for working with CVAT annotations:

  • Box: Bounding box annotations
  • Polygon: Polygon annotations with segmentation support
  • Mask: Efficient binary mask storage with RLE encoding
  • ImageAnnotation: Container for image annotations
  • JobStatus: Track annotation progress
  • Label: Label definitions with attributes
  • Attribute: Custom annotation attributes

View Types Documentation →

docs.title: Projects and Tasks
docs.text:
Manage CVAT projects and tasks:

  • Project: Container for tasks and labels
  • Task: Unit of work for annotation
  • Job: Individual annotation assignments

View Project Documentation → View Task Documentation → View Job Documentation →

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: For detailed usage examples, see the Examples section.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Contributions are welcome! Please feel free to submit a Pull Request.

docs.title: Annotations
docs.text: The Annotations class provides functionality to load, save and query CVAT annotations.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Load and save CVAT XML annotation files
  • Track job status information
  • Query task completion status
  • Access image annotations

docs.title: Loading Annotations
docs.text:
# Load annotations from XML file
annotations = Annotations.from_path("annotations.xml")

# Load annotations with job status
annotations = Annotations.from_path(
    "annotations.xml",
    "job_status.json"
)

docs.title: Querying Tasks and Images
docs.text:
# Get completed tasks and their images
completed_tasks = annotations.get_completed_tasks()
completed_images = annotations.get_images_from_completed_tasks()

# Get task status
task_status = annotations.get_task_status("1234")
# Returns: {"5678": "completed", "5679": "in_progress"}

docs.title: Creating CVAT Links
docs.text:
# Create CVAT link for an image
link = annotations.create_cvat_link("image1.jpg")
# Returns: "https://app.cvat.ai/tasks/453747/jobs/520016"

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• version: str - Version of the CVAT annotations format
  • project: Project - Project metadata and labels
  • tasks: List[Task] - List of tasks in the project
  • images: List[ImageAnnotation] - List of image annotations
  • job_status: List[JobStatus] - List of job status information

docs.title: from_path
docs.text:
@classmethod
def from_path(
    cls,
    xml_annotation_path: Union[str, Path],
    job_status_path: Optional[Union[str, Path]] = None
) -> Annotations

Load annotations from XML file and optionally include job status information.

docs.title: get_task_status
docs.text:
def get_task_status(self, task_id: str) -> Dict[str, str]

Get the status of all jobs for a given task. Returns a dictionary mapping job IDs to their states.

docs.title: get_completed_tasks
docs.text:
def get_completed_tasks(self) -> List[Task]

Get all tasks that have all jobs completed. A task is considered completed when all of its jobs are in the "completed" state.

docs.title: get_completed_task_ids
docs.text:
def get_completed_task_ids(self) -> List[str]

Get IDs of all tasks that have all jobs completed.

docs.title: get_images_from_completed_tasks
docs.text:
def get_images_from_completed_tasks(self) -> List[ImageAnnotation]

Get all images from completed tasks.

docs.title: create_cvat_link
docs.text:
def create_cvat_link(self, image_name: str) -> str

Create a CVAT link for the given image name. Returns a link in the format: https://app.cvat.ai/tasks/{task_id}/jobs/{job_id}

docs.title: Client
docs.text: The Client class is the main entry point for interacting with CVAT through next-cvat.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Initialize CVAT client from environment variables or credentials
  • Access and manage projects, tasks, and jobs
  • Download project data and annotations
  • Upload annotations and frames
  • Track job status

docs.title: Initialization
docs.text:
from next_cvat import Client

# Initialize from environment file
client = Client.from_env_file(".env.cvat.secrets")

# Initialize with credentials
client = Client(
    server_address="https://app.cvat.ai",
    username="user@example.com",
    password="password"
)

docs.title: Working with Projects
docs.text:
# Get a project by ID
project = client.project(217969)

# Download project data
project.download_("dataset/")

# Get project tasks
tasks = project.tasks()
for task in tasks:
    print(f"Task {task.id}: {task.name}")

docs.title: Working with Tasks
docs.text:
# Get a task by ID
task = client.task(906591)

# Create a new task
task = client.create_task(
    name="New Task",
    project_id=217969,
    frame_paths=["image1.jpg", "image2.jpg"]
)

# Delete a frame from a task
task.delete_frame("image1.jpg")

docs.title: Working with Jobs
docs.text:
# Get a job by ID
job = client.job(520016)

# Get job annotations
annotations = job.annotations()

# Update job status
job.update_status("completed")

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• server_address: str - CVAT server URL
  • username: str - Username for authentication
  • password: str - Password for authentication

docs.title: from_env_file
docs.text:
@classmethod
def from_env_file(cls, env_file: Union[str, Path]) -> Client

Initialize client from environment file containing CVAT credentials.

docs.title: project
docs.text:
def project(self, project_id: int) -> Project

Get a project by ID.

docs.title: task
docs.text:
def task(self, task_id: int) -> Task

Get a task by ID.

docs.title: job
docs.text:
def job(self, job_id: int) -> Job

Get a job by ID.

docs.title: create_task
docs.text:
def create_task(
    self,
    name: str,
    project_id: int,
    frame_paths: List[Union[str, Path]],
    **kwargs
) -> Task

Create a new task in a project with the given frames.

docs.title: create_token
docs.text:
def create_token(self) -> str

Create a new authentication token for the current user.

docs.title: Frame
docs.text:
The Frame class represents a frame in a CVAT task and provides methods for accessing frame data and images.

handler: python options: show_root_heading: true show_source: true

docs.title: Job Status
docs.text: The JobStatus class tracks the status of annotation jobs in CVAT.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• task_id: str - ID of the task this job belongs to
  • job_id: int - Unique identifier for the job
  • task_name: str - Name of the parent task
  • stage: str - Current stage of the job (e.g., "annotation", "validation")
  • state: str - Current state of the job (e.g., "completed", "in_progress")
  • assignee: Optional[Union[str, Dict[str, Any]]] - Username or details of the person assigned to the job

docs.title: Creating from Job Status Data
docs.text:
status = JobStatus(
    task_id="906591",
    job_id=520016,
    task_name="Batch 1",
    stage="annotation",
    state="completed",
    assignee="john.doe"
)

docs.title: Creating from CVAT SDK Job Object
docs.text:
status = JobStatus.from_job(job, task_name="Batch 1")
print(status.assignee_email)  # Get assignee's email

docs.title: from_job
docs.text:
@classmethod
def from_job(cls, job, task_name: str) -> JobStatus

Create a JobStatus from a CVAT SDK job object.

docs.title: assignee_email
docs.text:
@property
def assignee_email(self) -> Optional[str]

Get the assignee's email if available. Returns the username from the assignee dictionary or the assignee string directly.

docs.title: JobAnnotations
docs.text:
The JobAnnotations class represents annotations for a CVAT job and provides methods for managing annotation data.

handler: python options: show_root_heading: true show_source: true

docs.title: Project
docs.text: The Project class represents a CVAT project containing tasks and labels.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• id: str - Unique identifier for the project
  • name: str - Human-readable name of the project
  • created: str - Timestamp when the project was created
  • updated: str - Timestamp when the project was last updated
  • labels: List[Label] - List of label definitions for the project

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
project = Project(
    id="217969",
    name="My Project",
    created="2024-01-01 12:00:00.000000+00:00",
    updated="2024-01-01 12:00:00.000000+00:00",
    labels=[
        Label(name="car", color="#ff0000", type="any"),
        Label(name="person", color="#00ff00", type="any")
    ]
)

docs.title: Task
docs.text: The Task class represents a unit of work for annotation in CVAT.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• task_id: str - Unique identifier for the task
  • name: str - Human-readable name of the task
  • url: Optional[str] - Optional URL to access the task's data or API endpoint

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
task = Task(
    task_id="906591",
    name="Batch 1",
    url="https://app.cvat.ai/api/jobs/520016"
)

docs.title: job_id
docs.text:
def job_id(self) -> str

Extracts the job ID from the task's URL. Assumes the job ID is the last numeric part of the URL.

docs.title: Types
docs.text: The types module provides data models for CVAT annotations and related objects. These classes are used to represent various annotation types and their attributes.

docs.title: Box
docs.text:
A bounding box annotation in CVAT.

Boxes are used to define rectangular regions in images using top-left and bottom-right coordinates. They can be converted to polygons and segmentation masks.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION label

The label/class name for this box

TYPE: str

xtl

X-coordinate of the top-left corner

TYPE: float

ytl

Y-coordinate of the top-left corner

TYPE: float

xbr

X-coordinate of the bottom-right corner

TYPE: float

ybr

Y-coordinate of the bottom-right corner

TYPE: float

occluded

Whether this box is occluded (0 for no, 1 for yes)

TYPE: int

z_order

The z-order/layer of this box

TYPE: int

source

The source of this annotation (e.g. "manual", "automatic")

TYPE: str

attributes

List of additional attributes for this box

TYPE: List[Attribute]

docs.title: Polygon
docs.text:
A polygon annotation in CVAT.

Polygons are used to define regions in images using a series of connected points. They can be converted to segmentation masks and support various geometric operations.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION label

The label/class name for this polygon

TYPE: str

source

The source of this annotation (e.g. "manual", "automatic")

TYPE: str

occluded

Whether this polygon is occluded (0 for no, 1 for yes)

TYPE: int

points

List of (x,y) coordinates defining the polygon vertices

TYPE: List[Tuple[float, float]]

z_order

The z-order/layer of this polygon

TYPE: int

attributes

List of additional attributes for this polygon

TYPE: List[Attribute]

docs.title: Mask
docs.text:
A binary mask annotation in CVAT.

Masks are used to store pixel-wise segmentations efficiently using run-length encoding (RLE). They can be created from numpy arrays or PIL Images and support various operations.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION label

The label/class name for this mask

TYPE: str

source

The source of this annotation (e.g. "manual", "automatic")

TYPE: str

occluded

Whether this mask is occluded (0 for no, 1 for yes)

TYPE: int

z_order

The z-order/layer of this mask

TYPE: int

rle

Run-length encoded string representing the mask

TYPE: str

top

Top coordinate of the mask's bounding box

TYPE: int

left

Left coordinate of the mask's bounding box

TYPE: int

height

Height of the mask's bounding box

TYPE: int

width

Width of the mask's bounding box

TYPE: int

attributes

List of additional attributes for this mask

TYPE: List[Attribute]

docs.title: ImageAnnotation
docs.text:
Annotation data for a single image in CVAT.

Contains all annotation shapes (boxes, polygons, masks, polylines) associated with an image.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION id

Unique identifier for the image

TYPE: str

name

Filename of the image

TYPE: str

subset

Optional subset the image belongs to (e.g., "train", "test")

TYPE: Optional[str]

task_id

ID of the task this image belongs to

TYPE: Optional[str]

width

Image width in pixels

TYPE: int

height

Image height in pixels

TYPE: int

boxes

List of bounding box annotations

TYPE: List[Box]

polygons

List of polygon annotations

TYPE: List[Polygon]

masks

List of mask annotations

TYPE: List[Mask]

polylines

List of polyline annotations

TYPE: List[Polyline]

Example 
image = ImageAnnotation(
    id="1",
    name="frame_000001.jpg",
    subset="train",
    task_id="906591",
    width=1920,
    height=1080,
    boxes=[
        Box(label="car", xtl=100, ytl=200, xbr=300, ybr=400)
    ],
    masks=[
        Mask(label="person", points="100,200;300,400", z_order=1)
    ]
)

docs.title: JobStatus
docs.text:
Status information for a CVAT job.

Jobs are subdivisions of tasks that can be assigned to different annotators. Each job has a stage (e.g., "annotation") and state (e.g., "completed").

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION task_id

ID of the task this job belongs to

TYPE: str

job_id

Unique identifier for the job

TYPE: int

task_name

Name of the parent task

TYPE: str

stage

Current stage of the job (e.g., "annotation", "validation")

TYPE: str

state

Current state of the job (e.g., "completed", "in_progress")

TYPE: str

assignee

Username or details of the person assigned to the job

TYPE: Optional[Union[str, Dict[str, Any]]]

Example 
# Create from job status data
status = JobStatus(
    task_id="906591",
    job_id=520016,
    task_name="Batch 1",
    stage="annotation",
    state="completed",
    assignee="john.doe"
)

# Create from CVAT SDK job object
status = JobStatus.from_job(job, task_name="Batch 1")
print(status.assignee_email)  # Get assignee's email

docs.title: Project
docs.text:
A CVAT project containing tasks and labels.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION id

Unique identifier for the project

TYPE: str

name

Human-readable name of the project

TYPE: str

created

Timestamp when the project was created

TYPE: str

updated

Timestamp when the project was last updated

TYPE: str

labels

List of label definitions for the project

TYPE: List[Label]

Example 
project = Project(
    id="217969",
    name="My Project",
    created="2024-01-01 12:00:00.000000+00:00",
    updated="2024-01-01 12:00:00.000000+00:00",
    labels=[
        Label(name="car", color="#ff0000", type="any"),
        Label(name="person", color="#00ff00", type="any")
    ]
)

docs.title: Task
docs.text:
A CVAT task representing a unit of work for annotation.

Tasks are created within projects and contain images to be annotated. Each task can be split into multiple jobs for parallel annotation.

ATTRIBUTE DESCRIPTION task_id

Unique identifier for the task

TYPE: str

name

Human-readable name of the task

TYPE: str

url

Optional URL to access the task's data or API endpoint

TYPE: Optional[str]

Example 
task = Task(
    task_id="906591",
    name="Batch 1",
    url="https://app.cvat.ai/api/jobs/520016"
)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: This guide shows you how to use next-cvat for common tasks.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Create a .env.cvat.secrets file with your CVAT credentials:

```bash skip CVAT_HOST=https://app.cvat.ai CVAT_USERNAME=your_username CVAT_PASSWORD=your_password 

## Basic Workflow

Here's a complete example showing the main features:

```python skip
from next_cvat import Client
from pathlib import Path

# Initialize client
client = Client.from_env_file(".env.cvat.secrets")

# Get a project
project = client.project(217969)  # Use test project

# Create a new task
task = project.create_task_(
    name="Test Task",
    image_quality=70
)

try:
    # Upload images (replace with your actual image paths)
    task.upload_images_(
        image_paths=["path/to/image1.jpg", "path/to/image2.jpg"],
        image_quality=70
    )

    # Get task jobs
    jobs = task.jobs()
    job = jobs[0]  # Get first job

    # Get and update annotations
    annotations = job.annotations()

    # Add a bounding box annotation
    new_annotations = {
        "version": 0,
        "tags": [],
        "shapes": [{
            "type": "rectangle",
            "points": [40, 40, 60, 60],
            "frame": 0,
            "label_id": project.labels()[0].id,
            "group": 0,
            "source": "manual",
            "attributes": []
        }],
        "tracks": []
    }
    job.update_annotations_(new_annotations)

    # Check job status
    print(f"Job state: {job.state()}")
    print(f"Job stage: {job.stage()}")

finally:
    # Clean up
    project.delete_task_(task.id)

docs.title: Working with Projects
docs.text: ```python skip

docs.title: Get project metadata
docs.text: project = client.project(217969) with project.cvat() as cvat_project: print(f"Project name: {cvat_project.name}") print(f"Created: {cvat_project.created_date}")

docs.title: List tasks in project
docs.text:
tasks = project.tasks() for task in tasks: print(f"Task {task.id}: {task.name}") 

## Working with Tasks

```python skip
# Get a specific task
task = client.task(906591)

# List frames in task
frames = task.frames()
print(f"Number of frames: {len(frames)}")

# Delete a frame
task.delete_frame_(0)  # Delete first frame

docs.title: Working with Jobs
docs.text: ```python skip

docs.title: Get a specific job
docs.text: job = client.job(520016)

docs.title: Update job status
docs.text: job.update_status("completed")

docs.title: Get job annotations
docs.text:
annotations = job.annotations() print(f"Number of shapes: {len(annotations.annotations['shapes'])}") ```

Note: The code examples above are for illustration purposes. Replace the IDs and file paths with your actual values.
